contentChunks.htmlValue: Get to know Dynamic Color
For dynamic color dev libraries, visit Material color utilities on GitHub.

Dynamic color experiences are built with M3 color schemes. Beginning with Android 12, users can generate individualized schemes through wallpaper selection and other customization settings. With M3 as a foundation, user-generated colors can coexist with app colors, putting a range of customizable visual experiences in the hands of users.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Baseline scheme
2. Colors extracted from a wallpaper
3. Colors extracted from content

contentChunks.htmlValue:
User-generated schemes

A user-generated scheme is derived from a user’s personal wallpaper selection when they enable dynamic color. Their system UI, such as settings and built-in apps like the calculator and clock, will reflect color preferences at the individual device level.

contentChunks.altText: Primary, secondary, and tertiary color swatches and their corresponding container colors

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Content-based color schemes 

A content-based color scheme (content color) is derived from in-app content, such as album thumbnail images in a music app. 

Products can choose to apply content color to specific elements or screens as a way to enhance a color experience and support usability.

M3 baseline color & tokens

The baseline color scheme is a set of default colors for creating a light and dark theme UI. 

The baseline scheme is structured using color roles and tone relationships, which allow apps to seamlessly accept any user-generated color scheme in place of baseline color values.

Custom colors

Custom colors allow products to enable dynamic color but also reserve specific additional color roles that are essential to an app’s meaning. Often referred to as semantic color, a custom color allows flexibility alongside the baseline scheme and dynamic color.
Color from a wallpaper
User-generated color schemes integrate with Android apps that use the M3 color system.

A user’s wallpaper selection is the basis for the color extraction algorithm to build a color scheme that’s applied across a user's device and any apps that accept dynamic color.

A single source color is used to derive 5 tonal palettes that provide the basis for any light and dark theme use cases. Error colors are also slotted automatically, but are not technically included in the algorithmic extraction.

In addition to personal wallpaper as the source for individual color schemes, Pixel 6 users can also choose from several preset color schemes and wallpapers.

contentChunks.altText: Accent and neutral colors derived from a wallpaper image.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
From color extraction to color schemes

Once colors are selected from a wallpaper, they're translated into a spectrum of tones. The tones get assigned specific color roles that are mapped to Material components. A user-generated scheme produces the range of tones needed for both light and dark theme applications.

contentChunks.footer: Example of a light theme color selection generated by a red floral wallpaper.
contentChunks.altText: Light colors generated from a user-supplied image.

contentChunks.footer: Example of a dark theme color selection generated by a red floral wallpaper.
contentChunks.altText: Dark colors generated from a user-supplied image.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Color from content

Content-based color describes the color system’s capability to generate and apply a color schemes based on in-app content. In-app content colors can be derived from a range of sources, such as album artwork, a brand logo, or a video tile.

Why use content-based color

Colors derived from local content can enhance a person’s visual and emotional connection to their experience. In keeping with the M3 spirit, experiences can be personalized with local color derived from an individual’s in-app content preferences. 

In-app content provides a color source for any content-based color scheme, and can be applied within a specified area of an app, such as a set of components or a particular screen.

Build from a baseline scheme

A content-based scheme is a distinct set of colors from user-generated schemes and custom colors.

Apply content-based color to supplement a foundational scheme or user-generated scheme.

Starting from the M3 baseline color scheme or user-generated schemes will create a consistent color foundation to build upon. 

With a foundational color scheme established, colors can then be derived and applied based on in-app content.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Content-based scheme
2. Baseline or user-generated scheme

contentChunks.htmlValue:
When to apply

A music UI can take on a color scheme based on album art to emphasize content colors.

Apply content color in apps and areas where it can enhance brand identity and convey the M3 spirit of personalization. Content-based color can also be applied to support usability of specific features.

For example, a music app might derive color from a specific album’s artwork to build upon the personal connection to a music library.

For a news feed, content-based color may be applied from a given publication to differentiate brands and help users navigate the platform.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Music UI component
2. Album art
3. Music UI component with content-based scheme

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Generating content-based palettes

Products can specify an in-app image from which color is extracted to create a color scheme. The content-based scheme can then be applied to parts of an app, such as a set of components or a particular screen.

Color from image content

The process to create a color scheme from content is similar to that used for user-generated schemes. 

A single source color is extracted from an image and then used to derive five key colors.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Image content
2. Extracted source color
3. Accent colors
4. Neutral colors

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Specific tones are mapped into specific color roles that are mapped to Material components. 

A content scheme produces the range of tones needed for both light and dark theme applications.

Applying content-based color

To get started, consider where content exists in the UI and where content-based color can enhance a person’s experience. Look for components or clusters of components within a clearly defined space, like those in a standalone screen or in a section of a screen. If these components carry an association with personal content, there could be an effective opportunity to inherit content-based colors.

Build hierarchy & direct attention

When many types of information and actions share a screen, content-based color can be applied to add structure and hierarchy to a content-first experience. A content-based color helps direct attention with distinguishable element colors from other parts of the screen.

contentChunks.footer: A screen with numerous photo editing actions could use content color to differentiate key actions from secondary actions.
Color derived from the photo lends hierarchy to the screen by highlighting editing actions over the sharing actions.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Link and associate content on a screen

In lists and collections of repeated items that benefit from differentiation, content-based color can be used to associate relevant elements with each other. 

This can help people quickly distinguish and pair related information, such as a list item and its associated action.

contentChunks.footer: A screen with repeated element groups can benefit from stronger visual associations through color.
Color derived from the photo lends hierarchy to the screen by highlighting editing actions over the sharing actions.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Immersive content-based color

Full-screen content-based color applications can orient users within a particular space or task initiated from content, such as a media control or a purchase flow.

contentChunks.footer: In these music controls, color from the album art helps users maintain context between the minimized controls and the full screen player.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Pair content-based color with its source content

Keep the source for content-based color schemes visible on a screen using the content color. This way users are shown where a content-based color originates. 

Avoid applying content color in spaces where the content providing a color would not remain visible.

contentChunks.footer: To reinforce where a color is taken from, keep the content color’s source visible when content color is in use.
Don’t apply content color when the source of the color scheme will not be visible.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Two kinds of color schemes per screen maximum

Limit a screen to two color schemes from different source types. Too many color schemes on the same screen may lead to confusion and visual disarray. 

For example, a baseline or user-generated color scheme can be combined with a content-based color source from one type of content (such as album art).

contentChunks.footer: Avoid applying too many color schemes to the same screen. This example shows color schemes from three different types of sources: (1) a user’s wallpaper scheme (2) a chat avatar-based content color scheme (3) a content scheme derived from the message attachment content.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Content-based color shouldn’t replace semantic color

Use caution when applying content-based color in places where a semantic or conventional meaning is important for usability. 

For example, a common red error message or a common green positive action shouldn’t be replaced with dynamic content-based color because it may interfere with someone’s understanding.

contentChunks.footer: Apply content color to elements that don’t rely on color to indicate state or semantic meaning.

Don’t apply content-based color in ways that conflict with semantic or conventional colors, such as “delay” appearing green where typically it might take on an error color like red to signal importance or an action is needed.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Dynamic color & illustration

Dynamic color can be applied through mapping the color schemes to the different parts of the illustrations. This especially applies to illustrations that sits on a surface that will dynamically change. 

SVGs are the most efficient format for illustrations to adapt to dynamic colors as it has flexibility of control in applying the established color system to the different parts of a single illustration.

contentChunks.footer: Dynamic color can be applied through mapping the color schemes to the different parts of the illustrations. This especially applies to illustrations that sit on a surface that will dynamically change.
contentChunks.altText: An illustration with colors derived from a dynamic theme.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Color roles for illustration

Using a combination of primary, secondary, and tertiary variants, the tonal variation can create a flexible distribution of colors in an illustration. 

Tonal values are especially useful for indicating depth. Here's one example of how tones can be used in an illustration:

  1. Certain colors can be assigned that can be out of range of the color scheme for flexibility. Skin tones and hair color for instance are an exception to the color scheme to ground the character in reality.
  2. Primary 90 is applied to the trousers and Primary 80 is applied on the shadow cast on the trousers.
  3. Tertiary 90 is applied as an accent color.
  4. Secondary 80 is applied to the largest element of the illustration to make it less prominent.
  5. An additional selection of neutral variant is applied to the trousers to create depth and distinction between the clustered elements.
  6. Primary 70 is used to create more variation in tone.

contentChunks.altText: Diagram of an illustration containing both dynamic and fixed color elements.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Illustrations can also contain complexity in portraying depth. Dynamic color can be allocated to imply depth to create a distinct foreground and background relationship.

  1. Secondary 70-90 is applied to the background to make it less prominent.
  2. Skin tone and hair color are colors that should be considered outside of the color scheme
  3. Primary 50-80 is used in the main subject for prominence

contentChunks.altText: Diagram of an illustration showing lighter elements used in the background to simulate depth.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Here’s how the above image would look with a different color scheme but with the same color roles.

contentChunks.altText: A variation of the image above with a different color theme applied.

contentChunks.htmlValue: A full tonal color scheme can also be used for illustrations with less complexity. Here the tonal values of the secondary color are applied to a single illustration.

contentChunks.altText: An image using various tones of green

contentChunks.htmlValue: Continuity
Some elements in the illustration could stay the same across all color profiles. Here the skin tone is intended to stay the same for character continuity.

contentChunks.footer: Isolating some colors (like skin tone) lends continuity to individuals that need not shift when a new color profile is introduced.
contentChunks.altText: An image with two color themes applied in which the hair and skin color of people depicted are consistent between both images.

contentChunks.footer: Use caution if allowing all elements in an illustration to shift with different color profiles.
contentChunks.altText: An image with two color themes applied in which the hair and skin color of people are inconsistent between the two images.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Implementation

SVGs are the most efficient format for illustrations to adapt to dynamic colors as it has flexibility of control in applying the established color system to the different parts of a single illustration. This can be achieved through assigning M3 design tokens. However, this is not a requirement, and transparent pngs are still a valid format but the color is limited to one color scheme.

Existing PNGs can still work across dynamic backgrounds with the right color contrast.

contentChunks.footer: A single png can work across dynamic backgrounds with the right color contrast.
contentChunks.altText: An image with four different color themes applied.

contentChunks.footer: Use transparent pngs or svgs
contentChunks.altText: An illustration with a transparent background situated in the UI.

contentChunks.footer: Avoid floating illustrations with containers that contrast with a surface.
contentChunks.altText: An illustration with a solid white background situated in the UI.

contentChunks.footer: Use colors that create sufficient contrast against the tone of the background.
contentChunks.altText: An illustration with a darker primary color for sufficient contrast.

contentChunks.footer: Avoid very light colors as primary colors in light theme illustrations. Light tones will blend in with the color of the background, creating insufficient contrast.
contentChunks.altText: An illustration with a light primary color and low contrast.

contentChunks.footer: Use a combination of colors in the tone range of 40-100 on illustrations to create sufficient contrast against the tone of the background.
Avoid using colors using the 90-100 tone range on the majority of your illustration in light mode as it will blend with the color of the background, creating insufficient contrast.
contentChunks.altText: An image with light colors demonstrating low contrast.

contentChunks.footer: Use caution when applying tones from 0-30. These tones lead to a very high contrast look in illustrations.
contentChunks.altText: An image with dark colors demonstrating high contrast.
